abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings convey an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, and negligible
            institutional development impacts, in addition to
            unsatisfactory performances by both the Bank and Borrower.
            Among the many lessons learned it is suggested a
            multi-sector area-based program requires a functional
            decentralized policy framework, and a supportive
            management/administrative structure. In addition, where
            institutional capacity is limited, project design and
            implementation arrangements should be kept simple. The
            project proved to be difficult to implement because the
            design included several sectors, and the project was
            implemented through several Government ministries and
            agencies. Innovative programs need to be assessed and
            institutionalized before scaling-up. A more rigorous
            assessment and institutionalization of the innovative
            area-based program would have provided a sounder basis for
            scaling up the program in the form of the Child Development
            Project. Most importantly, investing time and resources on
            community preparedness contributes to the sustainability and
            impact of community-based initiatives. The project
            illustrated that initiatives that respond to
            community-defined priorities (like the water schemes and
            community schools in this case) have a better chance of
            being sustained, whereas initiatives that are largely
            supply-driven and through vertical programs (in this case
            the Integrated Management of Childhood Illnesses (IMCI) and
            Community Based Nutrition (CBN) require activities to create
            the demand in order to increase service utilization.
